div.h1: SPARQL Endpoint for British Museum Data

div.p: The data available in this endpoint are derived from an October 2015 dump generated by Matthew Lincoln and uploaded to here. This was a 48GB n-quad file that was pre-processed into triples to simplify named graphs into a single, default graph. The data have been imported into Apache Fuseki 3.x, a SPARQL 1.1-complaint endpoint that supports the full range of property paths, JSON-LD serialization, etc. It is more robust than the original British Museum SPARQL endpoint. At the time the export was made by Matthew Lincoln, the data were granted a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-NC-SA 4.0) license, which is irrevocable for this iteration of the data and future derivations.

The primary goal is the restore functionality of the data in order to facilitate the needs of various digital humanities projects that rely on cultural heritage objects in the British Museum. The BM has failed in its institutional obligations (as outlined by ICOM) to the general public by pulling the plug on its entire URI scheme and its Linked Open Data infrastructure. However, in order to make the data more usable for the purposes of research and aggregation, I plan to devise a workflow to transform the data (and this interface) over the course of several iterations:

ol.li: Coreferencing of thesauri. Many concept URIs have already been coreferenced to Wikidata, Nomisma.org, Pleiades Gazetteer of Ancient Places, the Getty vocabularies, etc. The aim is to coreference the British Museum thesaurus URIs (which are vital to aggregation projects) and re-insert matching concept URIs back into the RDF in this endpoint. Using APIs available from Geonames, Pleiades, or other geographic datasets, we will be able to extract coordinates for geographic entities, making it possible to conduct geographic analysis and visualization, a key feature of any cultural heritage digital collection.

Linked.art data model. The CIDOC-CRM model for British Museum objects was occasionally over-complex in some areas, such as production events. The modeling of these data was a one-off implementation for BM data alone. It was an early exemplar of CIDOC-CRM in large scale, but the model should be revisited in order to transform it to standards evolving from the linked.art community.

APIs. Eventually, search APIs will be built that conform to the linked.art specification. In the mean time, coreferencing to Pleiades and other identifiers will enable objects of the ancient world to be incorporated into Pelagios. It will be possible to generate an API that transorms CIDOC-CRM in the SPARQL endpoint directly into the Pelagios annotation RDF model. This has already been implemented in Nomisma.org and Kerameikos.org.

Improved UI. It will be possible to improve the user interface for the landing pages for British Museum objects and thesaurus concepts, including maps and images (when linked within the RDF data). It is possible to construct a human-readable and usable HTML page for objects while still making machine-readable available in a variety of serializations. A HTML page generated from a SPARQL endpoint can be more than list a list of RDF properties and literals/URIs. The final extension of UI design might also include integration with a Lucene-based search index to facilitate full-text search and faceted browsing.

div.p: This framework is a lightweight middleware running in Orbeon that shields Apache Fuseki from direct interaction from users on the web. It is opensource: https://github.com/ewg118/sparql-ui. The data are openly licensed (see terms above). Anyone, including the British Museum can freely take and use this application at any time.

a.title: Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities

div.p: This application is on a VM hosted by the Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities at the University of Virginia.
